translated: Jātaka🔽The Collection of Birth Stories (Jātakas)
The Chapter on Gandhāri
The Great Monkey Birth Story
“Having made yourself a bridge,
you saved those who were safe.
What are they to you, what are you to them,
you great monkey?”
“I am their king, their lord,
the protector of the herd.
For those who were overcome with grief,
you, O fearless one,
having lifted yourself up,
with your bow unstrung, a hundred times;
Then on the other side,
a strong bond of vines.

analyzed: chinnabbham iva vātena  nuṇṇaḥ rukkham upāgami
translated: Like a cloud blown away by the wind,🔽I fell down to a tree.
There I was in a precarious situation,
I grabbed a branch with my hands.
While I was hanging there,
by the branch and the vine;
Gradually descending with my feet,
the safe deer went away.
That bond does not torment me,
when I am dead it will not torment me;
They have happily obtained,
those for whom I ruled the kingdom.
This is a simile for you, O king,
listen to it, O fearless one;
For the king, the country, the warrior,
the army, and the city,
One who knows should seek the welfare of all,🔽a noble one who is skilled in what is beneficial.”
The king who knows should show kindness to all.
